Fig. 1. Research framework of U-Aerodrome.

Fig. 2. Visualization of the coordinate rotation process for trajectory points. The original coordinate system (X-O-Y) is rotated by an angle 𝜃rot to 
align the new axes (Xrot–O–Yrot) with the runway orientation.

Fig. 3. Illustration of covariance-based ellipse formation for Gaussian distributed trajectory points. Eigenvectors (red arrows) indicate the principal 
directions of spread, and their corresponding eigenvalues deﬁne the ellipse’s width and height. The ellipse encloses (1 −𝛼) × 100 % of all trajectory 
points, representing the risk-bounded dense air traﬃc zone.

Fig. 4. KDE-based probability density map of non-Gaussian distributed trajectory points. The color scale represents the kernel density estimate 
(KDE) value, corresponding to the likelihood of aircraft presence. The green contour denotes the risk-bounded dense air traﬃc zone enclosing 
(1 −𝛼) × 100 % of the total probability mass, serving as the safety envelope for aircraft trajectories.
Fig. 5. Illustration of standard instrument departure procedures with runway layout.
Fig. 6. Departure trajectories with classiﬁcation.
Fig. 7. Bivariate normality test results for trajectory distribution.

Fig. 8. Illustration of segregation boundary determination. Note that (a) Ellipse-shaped initial boundary for Gaussian-distributed trajectories. (b) 
Contour-shaped initial boundary for non-Gaussian-distributed trajectories. Both initial boundaries are then regularized using oriented bounding 
boxes (OBB).
Fig. 9. Vertical variation of airspace occupancy.
Fig. 10. Segregation boundary determination with and without Gaussian Distribution Hypothesis.

Fig. 11. Comparison of time-dependent and static airspace occupation volumes. The red dashed line denotes a volume ratio of 1. Ratios above 1 
indicate that the time-dependent boundary volume exceeds the static counterpart; ratios below 1 indicate the opposite.

Fig. 12. Spatiotemporal heatmap of hourly airspace occupancy by ﬂight level, distinguished by low, medium, and high utilization, color-coded in 
green, yellow, and red, respectively.
Fig. 13. Risk-bounded airspace reﬁnement.
Fig. 14. Operational occupancy proﬁles across ﬂight levels under varying risk constraints.

Table 1  Pseudocode and pipeline of U-Aerodrome.  1  Data input: Load historical trajectories, aerodrome layout, SIDs/STARs, and time stamps. Raw tracks, procedures → cleaned dataset.  2  Procedure-based grouping: Assign each trajectory to a published SID/STAR. Cleaned dataset, SIDs/STARs → grouped trajectories.  3  Equal-altitude sampling: Take one point per 100 ft level (keep latest if multiple). Grouped trajectories → level-wise point sets.  4  Deviation & normality test: Compute (𝑥dev, 𝑦dev) vs. (𝑥ben, 𝑦ben); apply normality test (HZ). Level-wise point sets → Gaussian / non-Gaussian ﬂag.  5  Parametric boundary (Gaussian): Estimate Σ, eigenpairs, scale ellipse by 𝜒2 (Eq. (4)–(12)). Level-wise points, 𝛼→ ellipse-shaped initial boundary.  6  Non-parametric boundary (non-Gaussian): Fit ̂𝑓(𝑥, 𝑦) and extract contour at risk 𝛼 (Eq. (13)–(17)). Level-wise points, 𝛼→ contour-shaped initial boundary.  7  OBB standardization: PCA align, min–max box, inverse rotate (Eq. (18)–(21)). Irregular initial boundary curve → regular OBB polygon.  8  Time-dependent update: Aggregate per-slice areas; Anderson–Darling for update decision (Eq. (22)). Time-indexed OBBs → hourly boundaries.  9  Operational occupancy: Apply no-overﬂy propagation across levels; build proﬁles. Hourly boundaries → operational occupancy by level.

Table 3  Safety metrics across various scenarios (risk levels 𝛼) for RWY 02C(DER)_2. The outside pro- portion is the observed fraction of trajectory points lying outside boundary (𝛼). Mean values  are averages across ﬂight levels; maxima are the worst-case across levels. While a larger (𝛼) comes with an increase outside proportion, all observed values satisfy the prescribed bound.

Table 4  Safety metrics for all runway groups at risk level 𝛼= 0.05. The outside proportion is the ob- served fraction of trajectory points lying outside (𝛼). Mean values are averages across ﬂight  levels; maxima are the worst-case across levels. All tested scenarios satisfy the prescribed  safety bound. Note that the rare observations of RWY 20R(DER)_1 are statistically insuﬃ- cient to compute its boundary, hence no outside proportion is counted.

Table 5  Eﬃciency metric of airspace availability (%) under diﬀerent scenarios (risk levels 𝛼), representing the potential  released percentage of airspace for UAM within the original no-ﬂy zone, numerically measured by the diﬀerence  between the volume of the original no-ﬂy zone and the occupied airspace by aircraft of RWY 02C(DER)_2.
